letter. Contractions and grammar structure changes and alters at times.

doesn't some obscure words in its spell-checker dictionary, but they're

isn't difficult to know when you're misspelling a word. Unfortunately, it 
doesn't tell you when you're using the wrong spelling of a word. Like your

comments.text:
Matthew,
 
Nobody doubts that all folklore has roots, connections or parallels in 
reality.  Some of it is even a wee bit true.

famous proof in all American history: "George Washington slept here. And

comments.author: David Lloyd-Jones

comments.text:
+David Lloyd-Jones Well, that's the thing. They have found ruins of ancient 
settlements around the Dead Sea valley that have shown signs of intense 
heat melting and one of the original settlements mentioned in the Bible, 
Zoar, still exists to this day, which only provides more evidence that 
these stories are, at the very least, based in fact. 

The point I'm trying to prove here is that you cannot dismiss anything as a 
"fairy tale" until you have enough evidence to disprove it and, so far, 
many of the Biblical accounts have either some root in truth or may have 
actually occurred, especially the Old Testament stories and Jesus's Story. 
Heck, to even go further and prove this crucial point, the First Century 
Historian, Josephus, even mention, vaguely, about Jesus by saying that a 
 group of Jews did believe that the Messiah did come and he recorded this 
history around 60-70 A.D., only thirty to forty years after Jesus's death. 

So, in the end, don't dismiss the Bible as simply a bunch of Fairy Tales 
because, in the end, there is quite  a bit of history behind it and many of 
the events recorded in there did occur.

top_comment.text:
Despite everything that's so far been put forward as a "missing link", no 
reputable palaeontologist, geneticist or anthropologist will stake his or 
her reputation that they have found unequivocal proof of any kind of 
evolutionary link between Homo Sapiens Sapiens (that's you and me, folks) 
and 'hominids' found in the fossil record. With ONE possible exception: 
Homo Sapiens Neanderthalensis -  Homo Sapiens Sapiens' contemporary; and 
a human who might have some residual genes in some modern day people. (But 
I think it wise to hold our breath on that ... claims of DNA links might 
yet prove to be unfounded)
Regarding PEKING "man"... aka 'Sinanthropus':
Peking Man was discovered in China, in the 1920s and 1930s, and like Java 
Man has since been renamed Homo erectus. The fossils, found about 25 miles 
from Peking (Beijing), consisted mostly of skull fragments (only five 
skulls were intact enough to gauge the brain capacity) and teeth, with very 
few limb bones. All of the original bones were lost between 1941 and 1945. 
(Fortunately, some excellent casts of the originals were made before their 
disappearance.) Peking Man was a bit smaller overall than the average human 
today, but in all respects falls within the modern range of variation, and 
its middle ear structure has been found to be just like ours.
As with Java Man, much of the truth surrounding Peking Man was kept from 
the public.  At the site were also found the remains of ten fully human 
inhabitants who quarried the limestone, built fires, and left behind a 
variety of tools. It seems that - far from being the ancestor of modern man 
- Peking Man was not only a contemporary, but may also have been his 
dinner. The evidence suggests that the larger people removed (and very 
possibly ate) the brains of the smaller Peking Man individuals.﻿

I believe you, but just about everyone can trace their lineage back to 
someone famous or someone who had something to do with someone famous. For 
instance, an old buddy of mine is an indirect descendant (i.e. 
great-great...uncle instead of grandfather) of the monk who administered 
last rites to William the Conqueror, while my direct ancestor was granted 
land by the same king.

My maternal ancestor was also the admiral of the ship on which Francis 
Scott Key wrote the Star Spangled Banner, and he was also the man who 
ordered the burning of Washington in the war of 1812.

And I'm pretty sure everyone else on this site can find someone equally 
impressive in their lineage. After all, the most recent common ancestor of 
everyone alive today was surprisingly recent.

the time. Eden was an important figure during the colonies being over North 
Carolina, he is thought to have protected Blackbeard. Blackbeard is seen

the Bath area.

My nan was brought up on a big farm in Kent and she told me a story of 
these 2 guys who payed my great grandfather £70 to use his farm in order to 
bury some 'treasure' they told my great grandfather that they didnt want 
anyone coming over (apart from him) but my nan was watching from behind a 
tree and she said that it was 3 chests along with 1 smaller one and a sword 
which was then wrapped up in a blanket, she asked my great grandfather what 
was in the chests and he only ever told her that "they were heavy" so she 
never knew what was in them, the farm is a housing estate now so finding it 
would be near impossible, also my great grandfather was given a luger by a 
polish pilot but my nan and her brother always ended up playing with it and 
one time shot at there house accidnetly so my great grandfather threw it 
down the farms well....its sad knowing the chests, sword and also the luger

top_comment.text:
As someone who lives in Arizona and fairly close to the Superstition 
Mountains, what I can tell you since I had to climb up there for a geology 
class field trip is that apparently all the gold that is "up in the 
mountains" is a lie. Many hikers go up the mountain looking for the gold 
and end up getting lost and in some cases don't get found. According to my 
teacher and geology stuff, the majority of the gold is burred below the 
surface where they still currently mine today and keep a VERY close watch. 
The only reason why we don't hear about too many people finding the gold is 
cause the obviously have high security in certain areas and well ya know, 
people go up trying to find the lost ditchmen's mine and die/get lost. : P﻿

You do know there weren't thousands of Templar in France right? There were 
thousands of Templar total, with the vast majority being in Northern Europe 
(during the end) and in Judea (Early stages) even a little bit in Iberia 
during the Reconquista. They didn't have thousands languishing so far from 
the front.

In France the Templar were tortured, this is factual. In fact some of the 
books I have read indicate that the French king tried to convince England 
to torture the Templar that were arrested there under orders of the Papacy.
The problem with the Templars was that a number of them did confess under 
torture, but none of the confessions made sense because they were saying 
whatever they thought the torturers wanted to hear, and (I can't remember 
the exact event the triggered it) they later recanted their confessions 
having them struck from record due to torture.

Would you mind providing reference to the fleets of Templar ships leaving 
France the morning of the arrests?

captions.text:
• From lost jewels in decades past to mysterious
skulls that may explain the origins of man

• We count 15 of the rarest treasures you
may or may not still be able to find in the

world to this day
15 - The Amber Room

• It was described as the eighth wonder
of the world, an 11-foot hall filled with

priceless artworks and amber gold-lead-edged
mirrors inlaid with precious jewels

• It was created for King Friedrich the
1st and later given to Russia's Peter the

Great in 1716, it's value? 142 million in
today's currency

• But in 1941 Nazis assaulted Leningrad
and claimed the Room, putting it on display

at Konigsberg Castle
• 4 years later, when Konigsberg surrendered,

the room was gone, vanished
• Was it destroyed? Hidden? Where is it

today? Nobody knows.
14 - The Alamo Treasure

• San Antonio, the famous American battle
of 188 men including Jim Bowie and Davey Crockett

attempting to fight off a Mexican army from
Santa Ana

• It was believed that in order to wage
this revolution against Mexico, the Texans

brought millions of dollars worth of treasure
in order to fund their own army

• However, all 188 men were killed at the
Alamo and knowledge of the treasure was lost

• Theories suggest it was buried beneath
the battle compound but excavations revealed

nothing
• Nobody knows where this treasure lies

13 - King John's Lost Crown Jewels
• The twelve hundreds, King John liked collecting

and stealing priceless items of jewellery
and gold for both himself, his guards and

soldiers
• On the 9th of October 1216, John travelled

to Norfolk but halfway across the marshes
he grew ill with dysentery, so he returned

to Newark Castle on a longer, safer road
• His treasure on the other hand, it took

a shorter more dangerous road through the
marshes, but it got trapped by the rising

tide and drowned, forever lost - and John
died not 10 days later

• The 70 million dollar collection of jewels
was never found

12 - Peking Man
• A famous historical and archaeological

find in the early 1930s - the only evidence
of Homo erectus pekinensis at the time, a

type of proto human from 780,000 years ago
• During World War 2 it and many other priceless

ancient human bones were shipped to the United
States via boat, but it never reached its

destination
• It was assumed the boat had been sunk

in 1945, with all treasure still lying somewhere
on the ocean floor

• Thankfully, 4 of the teeth made it to
the Paleontological Museum of Uppsala University

11 - The Barber Dimes
• This one is famous among coin collectors;

it's considered to be the rarest coin in American
history - even though over 4 million of them

were made
• The story goes, when the shipment was

being delivered to Phoenix from Colodaro,
treasure hunters accidentally tipped the wagon

train into the Black Canyon - leaving only
a dozen currently in existence

• Whoever finds the coins will find themselves
in wealth exceeding 3 million dollars

10 - The Ending to Hitchcock's "The White
Shadow"

• One of Alfred Hitchcock's earliest films
titled "The White Shadow" took him a lot of

effort to produce - he himself was the writer,
director, set designer and editor

• Unfortunately it bombed at the box office,
and all known copies began to disappear

• But in 2011, half the film showed up in
New Zealand

• An old collector had set aside some old
copies and never destroyed them, and it was

only after his grandson donated the copies
to the Film Archive that they made their reappearance

• However, the film's final half still remains
missing, and copies could still be out there

9 - Blackbeard's Treasure
• Everyone's heard about the story of the

famous pirate Blackbeard, but you may be surprised
to find out his treasure is very much real

and very much still up for grabs
• In the 2 years between 1716 and 1718,

Blackbeard raided heaps of ships sailing to
Spain - and he developed a foreboding reputation

because of it
• In 1718, he was decapitated by British

Lieutenant Robert Maynard and all knowledge
of the buried treasures whereabouts were lost

• In 1996, what was believed to be Blackbeard's
ruined ship was discovered near North Carolina,

but the loot remains unfound
• If you were planning to look for it, I

suggest the Caribbean Islands, Virginia's
Chesapeake Bay and the Cayman Island caves

8 - The Mobster's Treasure
• Dutch Shultz was deep in the mob scene

of 1930s America, and from it he amassed a
large fortune of wealth

• Since he was hunted by law enforcement,
he elected to keep his treasure hidden in

what was believed to be the Catskill Mountain
Range

• Then, in 1935, Shultz was gunned down,
and the treasure lost

• Current estimates put it at 5 to 10 million
dollars up for grabs in Phoenicia, New York

- though most believe floods would've washed
it all away over time

7 - The Missing Golden Eggs
• 1885, Russie, Tsar Alexander, third in

the house of Romanov commissioned the production
of golden "hen eggs" for his wife Empress

Maria
• The manufacturer Peter Carl Fabergé famous

for his work on quality and beauty, spent
the next 33 years creating over 50 eggs

• Then, in 1917, the Russian Revolution
executed the royal family and Peter, fearing

for his life, fled the country
• The eggs were stored in the Kremlin armoury

and some were sold to fund the new regime
• 8 of the original eggs are now missing,

their whereabouts unknown, still out there
somewhere, each egg worth over a hundred million

dollars
6 - The Secret City of Paititi

• This is a story in the vein of El Dorado,
an Inca city full of treasure lost with time

• It was the Spanish conquistadors that
drove the Inca civilisation deep into the

rainforests, but not before they could haul
their treasures with them

• So even after the Spanish claimed Paititi,
it was abandoned and worthless and the treasure

never found
• In Google Earth, it is shown in Brazil

that there were indeed what appears to be
Inca cities in the depths of the Brazilian

rainforest, and the gold may still be hidden
where modern man has never tread

5 - The Lost Dutchmen Mine
• The famous gold rush in the late 19th

century was full of secrets, and rightly so
since if word got out you'd discovered a bedrock

full of gold then everyone would come swarming
• Arizona, the Superstition Mountains, German

immigrant Jacob Waltz discovered a massive
cache of gold which lead him to become wealthy

until his death in the late 1800s
• Thousands, tens of thousands of miners

searched far and wide for the location of
this mine, but nobody found it

• It's highly possible it's still there
to this day, just waiting to be excavated

once again
4 - Leon Trabuco's Gold

• The 1930s, United States in the Great
Depression, dollar value at an all-time low

and gold quickly on the rise
• Mexican millionare Leon Trabuco and his

partners stash up over sixteen tons of gold
and hid it in the New Mexico Desert, waiting

for gold prices to peak on the market
• Then someone unexpected happened: the

Gold Act was introduced prohibiting the private
ownership of gold - which left Leon with a

large stack of worthlessness
• Once he and his partners died, the golds

whereabouts was lost but still out there,
somewhere, likely buried next to E.T game

cartridges
3 - The Oak Island Money Pit

• 1500AD, Oak Island off the southeast coast
of Nova Scotia

• 1795, some kids find a circular depression
in the ground, and as they dug it was revealed

traces of pickaxes and planks, as if someone
had gone deep underground then hurriedly filled

it back in
• Over the centuries, the rumour grew pirates

like Captain Kidd and Blackbeard might've
dumped their treasure in this spot, and they

even found an inscription on a stone that
read: "forty feet below, two million pounds

lie buried"
• But after many years of digging down 72

meters, nothing has been found so far, and
it's led to the deaths of 6 people

2 - Treasures of Lima
• Cocos Island, 17th and 18th century, Europeans

continually plundered South America and stored
treasures in Lima, Peru

• But then the Peruvian War forced everyone
out in 1820 and the treasure passed into the

hands of Captain William Thompson, who decided
to enter the plundering business

• He buried the treasure just off Costa
Rica, but it wasn't specified where and nobody

knows where to look, so the treasure remains
hidden to this day

1 - The Ark of the Covenant
• The ornate chest designed by God himself

to house two stone tablets: the Ten Commandments
• 607 BC. Jerusalem, Solomon's Temple was

besieged and overthrown by the Babylonians,
leading to over a million deaths and 70 years

of exile for the survivors
• When they returned, the Ark was gone

• It was either kept hidden during the Babylonian
assault and the secret location lost due to

how many were slaughtered, or destroyed
• Where is it now, and does it even exist?
Nobody knows. Except for Indiana Jones.

title: 15 Lost Treasures You Can Still Find That'll Make You Rich
